page.title: 06The Stroudwater Canal
page.content:
Cut in the 1790's from Framilode on the River Severn to Wallbridge at Stroud, to cope with the increased demand for coal following the introduction of steam power in the woollen and other industries further up the Stroud Valley, it became part of the canal link from the Severn to the Thames. It has not been used as a navigable waterway for at least 60 years, and was blocked by road improvements at the A38 Bristol to Gloucester Road.
Volunteer organisations concerned with our heritage are restoring the lock gates but as the link road from the A38 to the M5 Motorway is now built on part of the canal bed it will not be possible to reconnect it with the Severn along its original path.
